BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 13, 1912.

VOL. XVI, NO. 2

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

VIRGINIA WINS TRACK MEET

ATHLETIC POLICIES REVISED

VARSITY TOURNAMENT PLANS

GETZ, GILLET AND LEE NOMINEES

Charlottesville Athletes Set Two New
Records in the Dual Meet—Horrax
and Wagner Star for Hopkins.

Eleventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Articles of the Policies Replaced by New Articles.

Annual Affair to Start May 20—Big Entry List Hoped for The New
Courts to Be Used.

Mass-Meeting Also Nominates Rcosevelt
and Bryan—Corner Resolutions
Are Again Presented.

The strong University of Virginia track team defeated - Hopkins
in a dual meet last Saturday at
Charlottesville, Va. with a total of
39. But
'
49 points against Hopkins,
for the unfortunate accident which
kept Captain Lee from running this
spring, Hopkins would have won
the meet. Lee- started in the mile,
but his knee was not strong enough
to stand the strain, and although he
has run the mile 9 seconds faster
than the time made by Cooke, the
winner, he was unable to even place.
Captain Cooke, of the Virginia
team, showed remarkable ability on
Saturday, as after winning the mile,
he entered the half-mile event and
smashed the Virginia record, winning in the fast time of i minute
594% seconds. Walters and Gooch
sprang • surprises when they both
cleared over 23 feet in the winning
'broad jump. 'Walters' jump of • 23
feet 2 inches is a new Virginia
recora. Horrax jumped better than
in any meet this season, but was
unable to place.
Wagner repeated his, victories of
the previous Saturday by taking
both places in the ioo and 220 yards
dashes. He again equalled the Hopkins record of io seconds flat for
the century event. - Horrax was the
chief individual point winner of the
meet. He won the high jump with
the very good jump of 5 feet ii
inches. He also won the 120-yard
high hurdles and placed second in
the pole-vault. Dignan won the
shot-put for Hopkins as usual,

The Athletic Board has acted .in
good faith. At the Student Council
mass-meeting, held some time ago,
the Board's representative excused
the obnoxious Eleventh, Twelfth,
Thirteenth, and Fourteenth Articles
of the new athletic policies on the
ground that they were unfortunately phrased, and conveyed a meaning that was not intended. Upon
this assurance the meeting refused
to pass a vote of censure upon the
policies. The Board has made good
its words by its deeds, and at its
last meeting the four articles in
question were stricken from the
policies and two new ones substitute(I.
The new articles read as follows:
Article ii. The Director of the
gymnasium, by reason of his position as defined in the Constitution
and By-Laws of the Athletic Association and in the UniVersity Circular, seems to occupy a position
admirably calculated to be the clearing-house for athletic matters. New
policies, resolutions or recommendations from meetings of students or
alumni, weekly reports of the graduate managers, criticisms or suggestions from individual alumni or
members of the faculty, should
come to him that he may be in constant touch with all matters pertaining to athletics and thus be in the
best position to bring to any question at issue all the facts in the case.
Article 12. The Athletic Beard,
composed of the elected representatives of the Athletic Association, is
the final authority in all branches of
athletics, and is restricted only by
the veto power which the Board of
Trustees vests in sonic one member
of the Athletic Board.
The articles which are thus replaced read as follows:
Article ii. The Director of the
gymnasium, by virtue of his position, is the only absolute head of
athletics. He may call into consultation any one he desires; but the
authority for the final decision rests
with hint
Article 12. Any new athletic
policy or meetings for the discussion of athletic policy, held either
by students or alumni, should be
brought before the Director of the
gyninasium.
Article 13. The graduate manager should report to the Director
of the gymnasium at least weekly
as to the conduct of his office.
Article 14. Under the Director
of the gymnasium the Athletic

In its announcement, as printed
below, the 'Varsity Tennis Committee makes public its plans for the
tournament this year. They wish
every man in the University who
plays tennis to enter the tournament this year and make it one
grand success. Last year there
were thirty-six entries in the tournament and there should be at least
forty this year.
Handsome prizes will be given
the winner of the singles event, and
also the runner-up. The winning
team and the runners-up in doubles
will also receive prizes. A consolation event will be played, for which
all those players are eligible who are
defeated in the first match actually
played. A prize will be offered as
usual for the winner of this event.
Play will not start until 4.30 each
afternoon, so that no one will have
to cut "lab" in order to play. In
addition, all the courts will be used
so that no one will be compelled to
remain waiting around for his turn
to play. The four cinder and three
dirt courts • will be used. A good
many of the various winners from
previous 'Varsity tournaments are
still in the University, so there will
undoubtedly be some "class" displayed.
The tournament was won last
year by Perce, a graduate student,
who has since left. Huck, the runner-up, is still here, as is Fulton,
the winner of the consolations.
Belt, captain of the tennis team
and runner-up in doubles for the
last two years, is also eligible. A
number of entries are expected
from the Medical School. As the
drawings will be made on Saturday, the Committee urges everyone
to hand in their entries eagdy, without waiting to be asked for them.
The official announcement is as follows:
MENT VOR 1912.
The 1912 annual 'Varsity tennis
tournament will commence this
year on May 20. Play will commence at 4.30 each afternoon and
will continue until the tournament
is over. The events will be singles
and doubles and Consolation singles.
A mixed doubles event will be
added if there is sufficient' demand
for it. Prizes will be awarded the
winner flcl runner-up in both the
singles and doubles and the winner
in the consolation event. All players are eligible for the consolations
who are defeated in the first match

Charles Leland Getz, George Gillet, and Frederic C. Lee were the
three candidates nominated for the
presidency of the Athletic Association at the nominating- meeting held
in Hopkins Hall last Wednesday.
A general spirit of mischief pervaded the meeting and for the various offices many names were presented whose owners have no intention of appearing as serious candidates. Because of a rule of the
Athletic Association, however, they
will be unable to withdraw until
next Wednesday. The uncertainty
as to just who will withdraw and
who will not is likely.to cause considerable confusion among members
of the Association in determining
for whom to cast their vote.
The complete list of nominations
is as follows:
President—Frederick C. Lee, C.
L. Getz and George Gillet.
Vice-President—Walter Sutton,
Augustus Sattler and John Huck.
Corresponding Secretary—Geo.
Gillet, Herbert Catlin, W. N.
Brown, and J. L. Dorsey.
Medical Delegate—Gilbert Horrax, Benjamin Tappan and John
Morton.
Alumni Delegate—W. C.
Schmeisser.
Graduate Delegate—Harry Wagner, Frederic Lee, John Huck, Edward Hulburt, T. B. Price and J. B.
Reeside.
Senior Delegate—E. J. Pieper,
Julian Sears, Dushane Penniman,
Augustus Sattler, Ellis Ellicott,
Lynn Meekins, Edmund Donoho,
Paul Carter, Emory Niles.
Junior Delegate—Victor Bridgman, Guy Holyday, Butts Sutton,
Harry Corner, R. Leibensperger,
Peter Porter, J. L. Dorsey, A. L.
Hammond and Lawson 'Wilkins.
Sophomore Deleg at e — John
Branham, Tom Troxall, Claude Uhler, Allan Voshell, Emmett Spencer
and Bruce Mason.
Among other persons nominated
were Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, and William Jennings
Bryan.
Before the nominations were
opened Mr. Harry E. Corner pre—
sented a set if resolutions, the intent of \vhic was the same as that
of the resc Ations which he presented at the student council mass::
meting a few weeks ago. The' resolutions were given their first
reading and will be taken up for
final consideration at the mass-meeting next Wednesday. The resolu-

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 13, 1912

We regret to announce that Mr.
Lindsay Rogers, Mr. Donald K.
Belt, and Mr. Thomas Brooke
Price, .who have contributed so
much to the success of THE NEWSLETTER during the past three years,
have resigned from the board of
'editors in view of their approaching graduation. At the last meeting of the board, Mr. John Shard
Dickinson was . elected Editor-inChief to succeed Mr. Rogers, and
Mr. Guy T. 0. Hollyday, Business
Manager, to succeed Mr. Belt. The
retiring editors were given a vote
of thanks for their services to the
paper.
A Few Words of Explanation.
The voting members of the Athletic Board, as that board is at
present constituted, are of three
kinds. The first class comprises the
officers of the Athletic Association,
consisting of a president, a vicepresident and acorrespondina secre-:
tary. The second class includes those
members of the board who are not
drawn from the undergraduate department ; namely, a graduate manager„three alumni delegates, a delegate from the Medical School, and
a delegate from the graduate department. The third includes representatives of the undergraduates
—two senior delegates, a junior
delegate and a sophomore delegate.
It .can thus be seen that four members of the board must always be
undergraduates. Six must always
be graduates. The remaining three,
the officers of the Athletic Association, may be either graduates or undergraduates indifferently.
The opinion seems to be almost
unanimous that a majority of the
board should be undergraduates.
The undergraduate department supplies a majority of the men on our
. athletic teams. It supplies an even
larger proportion of the candidates
for teams. It supplies a great part

of our athletic enthusi.asm. There
seems to be no reason why the
board which directs our athletic
policy should not be principally
made up from the department
which is the mainstay of our athletics. Under the present allotment
of representation there is only one
way in which an undergraduate
majority on the board can be secured. If undergraduates are elected to fill all three offices of the
Athletic Association, then there will
be seven undergraduates on the
board as against six graduates. But
this is not a very usual occurrence.
It is in many cases not advisable.
Frequently a man no longer a member of the undergraduate department possesses long and valuable
experience which the Athletic Association desires to take advantage
of by electing him to the responsible
position of president. The officers
of the Athletic Association should
be chosen for their fitness, and the
department from which they come
should not have to be taken into
consideration.
The matter can be looked at from
standpoint. At present
an
six places on the board are definitely guaranteed to men who are
not undergraduates. To the undergraduates only four places are
assured. It is manifestly unfair
that the departments of the University which take a relatively small
part in athletics should always be
certain of a larger share of influence
than the one department which our
athletics could not possibly get along
without. To do awarwith this unfairness is the purpose of the -Corner reso:utions. which will come up
for final consideration at the massmeeting next Wednesday. The increase in the membership of the
board proposed by these resolutions
is not sufficient to render that body
unwieldy. The resolutions merely
guarantee to the undergraduate
students that power in shaping the
athletic policies of the University
which is their due ; and THE NEWSLETTER can see no reasonable objection which can be urged against
the adoption of the resolutions.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 13, 1912.
THIRD LEAGUE GAME LOST
Lehigh Lacrosse Team Wins First Time
Since Captain Gail Was in Swaddling Clothes- Score,9 to 3.

As a sort of panacea for nearly
a quarter of a century of defeats,
Lehigh managed to slip a score of
9 to 3 over on the 'Varsity last
Compared with the
Saturday.
Homewood "billiard table," the
South Bethlehem field looked as if
some Pennsylvania Dutch farmer
had "turned it under" for a garden.
.Besides this unwonted roughness, a
220-yard straight-away behind one
goal necessitated a complex field
rule which was hard to get used to.
These small annoyances did not
tend to strengthen a team weakened
by the loss of Gillet and Troxell.
To do them justice, however, the
Opposing team was good, showing
the effects of Jack Grimes' training, who for several years coached
Mount Washing-ton. This phenomenal training was chiefly exemplified
in the stick work, the roughness of
which was worthy of the toughest
Canuck in any back alley of Montreal. Our men tried to retaliate,
but showed remarkable lack of
training in this department.
Although we started the scoring,
the first half ended 5 to 1. In the
second period 'Lehigh kept up her
-fast work until three more opals'
were made and then slowed'' up,
sending in many substitutes. Captain Gail then managed 'to get
two goals, but Lehigh immediately'
steadied, and F. L. Speed sent in
the ninth point for Lehigh just as
the game ended.
All of the "subs," Angell, Price,
Sears and Richardson, made good.
These men stemmed the tide of defeat, and for the last, ten minutes
of the game, the 'Varsity had things
its own way. Though two league
games were lost, Captain Gail and
the coaches are to he congratulated
on winning four games out of seven
Saturday.
Captain Kennedy, St. John, Hartegall and Williams were Lehigh's
mainstays, although the work of all
the men was highly commendable.
Captain Gail. Huck and Easter did
best for the 'Varsity. The line-up:
Hopkins—Sutton, g... Schmeisser, p.;
Niles, ca.; Huck, id.; Ellicott, 2d.; Benedict, 3d.: Hollvday, C. Paulus, 3a.;
Everton, 2a..; Gail, ia.; Voshell,
Easter, ill.
Lehigh—Hart, g.; Carson. p.; Rayner,
cn.; F. B. Speed, id.; Hartegan, 2d.;
Kennedy, 3d.; St. John. c.: Buck, 3a.;
Jay, 2a.; Williams, Ia.; Schultz. oh.;
Donaldson, ill.
Goals—Williams (3), St. John (2),
Buck, Hartegan. Jay, F. B. Speed; Gail
(2), Voshell. Substitutes—Johns Hopkins—Angell for Everton ; Sears for
Ellicott; Richardson for Voshell ; Price
for Benedict. Lehigh—Martin for Schultz,
P. R. Sneed for Donaldson: Perkins for
T-Tart Carpenter fcr Martin. Referee—
Brior, St. Johns. Timekeepers—Dorsey,
Johns Honkins; Edwards, Lehigh.. Goal
tunnires—Barger, Johns Hopkins; McConner, Lehigh. Time of halves, 35
minutes.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
which, upon request, will be withheld.)

May II, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

So much might be said apropos
of Mr. B. B's letter in the last issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER that we had
almost decided not to say anything.
But one or two things certainly
should be said. First of all, then,
let us recognize the fact that no
university proposes to give to its
students all the training—mental,
moral, physical and social—which it
is desirable for college graduates
to have. In order to provide for
students this training which the
university authorities think they are
not fitted to give, Y. M. C. A.'s,
athletic associations, glee clubs, literary societies, and fraternities have
been formed by the students themselves. If men know nothing about
the modern religions it is the fault
of the Y. M. C. A., of the churches,
of anybody rather that that of the
university professor. Cardinal
Newman has said that the object
of a university is not to give religious training. If a student graduates from a university weaker
than when he entered, the fault lies
with the athletic association for
taking his $5 locker fee and not giving him a real opportunity to take
physical exercise. A "stag" college should not be expected to teach
social finesse.
The question now naturally arises
whether the interests of the students would best be served if as
Mr. B. B. actually proposes, the
Hopkins faculty took the responsibility of teaching such subjects as
the present-day relation between
the European States. We think
not. Any course about modern
conditions would in the nature of
things be so broad that it would
have to be shallow. Nobody would
take it seriously. Nobody would
like to get into an argument with a
professor who has ideas so fundamentally different from his that
there is no common ground upon
which they could stand: a literary
society, on the other hand, is admirably adapted to disperse knowledge
about modern politics and to sth-nulate interest in good novels and
magazines. A member of such a
society is induced to work hard for
the honors he expects to receive.
All those with whom he has to argue are his equals. Those who get
along well in their lessons can devote a great deal of time to such an
organization; those who need to
spend most of their time on their
lessons, are only required to spend
one hour a week for the meeting.
The English system is no more elastic than this.

VIRGINIA WINS TRACK MEET

ATHLETIC POLICIES REVISED

VARSITY TOURNAMENT PLANS

GETZ, GILLET AND LEE NOMINEES

Charlottesville Athletes Set Two New
Records in the Dual Meet—Horrax
and Wagner Star for Hopkins.

Eleventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Articles of the Policies Replaced by New Articles.

Annual Affair to Start May 20—Big Entry List Hoped for The New
Courts to Be Used.

Mass-Meeting Also Nominates Rcosevelt
and Bryan—Corner Resolutions
Are Again Presented.

The strong University of Virginia track team defeated - Hopkins
in a dual meet last Saturday at
Charlottesville, Va. with a total of
39. But
'
49 points against Hopkins,
for the unfortunate accident which
kept Captain Lee from running this
spring, Hopkins would have won
the meet. Lee- started in the mile,
but his knee was not strong enough
to stand the strain, and although he
has run the mile 9 seconds faster
than the time made by Cooke, the
winner, he was unable to even place.
Captain Cooke, of the Virginia
team, showed remarkable ability on
Saturday, as after winning the mile,
he entered the half-mile event and
smashed the Virginia record, winning in the fast time of i minute
594% seconds. Walters and Gooch
sprang • surprises when they both
cleared over 23 feet in the winning
'broad jump. 'Walters' jump of • 23
feet 2 inches is a new Virginia
recora. Horrax jumped better than
in any meet this season, but was
unable to place.
Wagner repeated his, victories of
the previous Saturday by taking
both places in the ioo and 220 yards
dashes. He again equalled the Hopkins record of io seconds flat for
the century event. - Horrax was the
chief individual point winner of the
meet. He won the high jump with
the very good jump of 5 feet ii
inches. He also won the 120-yard
high hurdles and placed second in
the pole-vault. Dignan won the
shot-put for Hopkins as usual,

The Athletic Board has acted .in
good faith. At the Student Council
mass-meeting, held some time ago,
the Board's representative excused
the obnoxious Eleventh, Twelfth,
Thirteenth, and Fourteenth Articles
of the new athletic policies on the
ground that they were unfortunately phrased, and conveyed a meaning that was not intended. Upon
this assurance the meeting refused
to pass a vote of censure upon the
policies. The Board has made good
its words by its deeds, and at its
last meeting the four articles in
question were stricken from the
policies and two new ones substitute(I.
The new articles read as follows:
Article ii. The Director of the
gymnasium, by reason of his position as defined in the Constitution
and By-Laws of the Athletic Association and in the UniVersity Circular, seems to occupy a position
admirably calculated to be the clearing-house for athletic matters. New
policies, resolutions or recommendations from meetings of students or
alumni, weekly reports of the graduate managers, criticisms or suggestions from individual alumni or
members of the faculty, should
come to him that he may be in constant touch with all matters pertaining to athletics and thus be in the
best position to bring to any question at issue all the facts in the case.
Article 12. The Athletic Beard,
composed of the elected representatives of the Athletic Association, is
the final authority in all branches of
athletics, and is restricted only by
the veto power which the Board of
Trustees vests in sonic one member
of the Athletic Board.
The articles which are thus replaced read as follows:
Article ii. The Director of the
gymnasium, by virtue of his position, is the only absolute head of
athletics. He may call into consultation any one he desires; but the
authority for the final decision rests
with hint
Article 12. Any new athletic
policy or meetings for the discussion of athletic policy, held either
by students or alumni, should be
brought before the Director of the
gyninasium.
Article 13. The graduate manager should report to the Director
of the gymnasium at least weekly
as to the conduct of his office.
Article 14. Under the Director
of the gymnasium the Athletic

In its announcement, as printed
below, the 'Varsity Tennis Committee makes public its plans for the
tournament this year. They wish
every man in the University who
plays tennis to enter the tournament this year and make it one
grand success. Last year there
were thirty-six entries in the tournament and there should be at least
forty this year.
Handsome prizes will be given
the winner of the singles event, and
also the runner-up. The winning
team and the runners-up in doubles
will also receive prizes. A consolation event will be played, for which
all those players are eligible who are
defeated in the first match actually
played. A prize will be offered as
usual for the winner of this event.
Play will not start until 4.30 each
afternoon, so that no one will have
to cut "lab" in order to play. In
addition, all the courts will be used
so that no one will be compelled to
remain waiting around for his turn
to play. The four cinder and three
dirt courts • will be used. A good
many of the various winners from
previous 'Varsity tournaments are
still in the University, so there will
undoubtedly be some "class" displayed.
The tournament was won last
year by Perce, a graduate student,
who has since left. Huck, the runner-up, is still here, as is Fulton,
the winner of the consolations.
Belt, captain of the tennis team
and runner-up in doubles for the
last two years, is also eligible. A
number of entries are expected
from the Medical School. As the
drawings will be made on Saturday, the Committee urges everyone
to hand in their entries eagdy, without waiting to be asked for them.
The official announcement is as follows:
MENT VOR 1912.
The 1912 annual 'Varsity tennis
tournament will commence this
year on May 20. Play will commence at 4.30 each afternoon and
will continue until the tournament
is over. The events will be singles
and doubles and Consolation singles.
A mixed doubles event will be
added if there is sufficient' demand
for it. Prizes will be awarded the
winner flcl runner-up in both the
singles and doubles and the winner
in the consolation event. All players are eligible for the consolations
who are defeated in the first match

Charles Leland Getz, George Gillet, and Frederic C. Lee were the
three candidates nominated for the
presidency of the Athletic Association at the nominating- meeting held
in Hopkins Hall last Wednesday.
A general spirit of mischief pervaded the meeting and for the various offices many names were presented whose owners have no intention of appearing as serious candidates. Because of a rule of the
Athletic Association, however, they
will be unable to withdraw until
next Wednesday. The uncertainty
as to just who will withdraw and
who will not is likely.to cause considerable confusion among members
of the Association in determining
for whom to cast their vote.
The complete list of nominations
is as follows:
President—Frederick C. Lee, C.
L. Getz and George Gillet.
Vice-President—Walter Sutton,
Augustus Sattler and John Huck.
Corresponding Secretary—Geo.
Gillet, Herbert Catlin, W. N.
Brown, and J. L. Dorsey.
Medical Delegate—Gilbert Horrax, Benjamin Tappan and John
Morton.
Alumni Delegate—W. C.
Schmeisser.
Graduate Delegate—Harry Wagner, Frederic Lee, John Huck, Edward Hulburt, T. B. Price and J. B.
Reeside.
Senior Delegate—E. J. Pieper,
Julian Sears, Dushane Penniman,
Augustus Sattler, Ellis Ellicott,
Lynn Meekins, Edmund Donoho,
Paul Carter, Emory Niles.
Junior Delegate—Victor Bridgman, Guy Holyday, Butts Sutton,
Harry Corner, R. Leibensperger,
Peter Porter, J. L. Dorsey, A. L.
Hammond and Lawson 'Wilkins.
Sophomore Deleg at e — John
Branham, Tom Troxall, Claude Uhler, Allan Voshell, Emmett Spencer
and Bruce Mason.
Among other persons nominated
were Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, and William Jennings
Bryan.

opened Mr. Harry E. Corner pre—

meting a few weeks ago. The' resolutions were given their first
reading and will be taken up for
final consideration at the mass-meeting next Wednesday. The resolu-

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 13, 1912

We regret to announce that Mr.
Lindsay Rogers, Mr. Donald K.
Belt, and Mr. Thomas Brooke
Price, .who have contributed so
much to the success of THE NEWSLETTER during the past three years,
have resigned from the board of
'editors in view of their approaching graduation. At the last meeting of the board, Mr. John Shard
Dickinson was . elected Editor-inChief to succeed Mr. Rogers, and
Mr. Guy T. 0. Hollyday, Business
Manager, to succeed Mr. Belt. The
retiring editors were given a vote
of thanks for their services to the
paper.
A Few Words of Explanation.
The voting members of the Athletic Board, as that board is at
present constituted, are of three
kinds. The first class comprises the
officers of the Athletic Association,
consisting of a president, a vicepresident and acorrespondina secre-:
tary. The second class includes those
members of the board who are not
drawn from the undergraduate department ; namely, a graduate manager„three alumni delegates, a delegate from the Medical School, and
a delegate from the graduate department. The third includes representatives of the undergraduates
—two senior delegates, a junior
delegate and a sophomore delegate.
It .can thus be seen that four members of the board must always be
undergraduates. Six must always
be graduates. The remaining three,
the officers of the Athletic Association, may be either graduates or undergraduates indifferently.
The opinion seems to be almost
unanimous that a majority of the
board should be undergraduates.
The undergraduate department supplies a majority of the men on our
. athletic teams. It supplies an even
larger proportion of the candidates
for teams. It supplies a great part

of our athletic enthusi.asm. There
seems to be no reason why the
board which directs our athletic
policy should not be principally
made up from the department
which is the mainstay of our athletics. Under the present allotment
of representation there is only one
way in which an undergraduate
majority on the board can be secured. If undergraduates are elected to fill all three offices of the
Athletic Association, then there will
be seven undergraduates on the
board as against six graduates. But
this is not a very usual occurrence.
It is in many cases not advisable.
Frequently a man no longer a member of the undergraduate department possesses long and valuable
experience which the Athletic Association desires to take advantage
of by electing him to the responsible
position of president. The officers
of the Athletic Association should
be chosen for their fitness, and the
department from which they come
should not have to be taken into
consideration.
The matter can be looked at from
standpoint. At present
an
six places on the board are definitely guaranteed to men who are
not undergraduates. To the undergraduates only four places are
assured. It is manifestly unfair
that the departments of the University which take a relatively small
part in athletics should always be
certain of a larger share of influence
than the one department which our
athletics could not possibly get along
without. To do awarwith this unfairness is the purpose of the -Corner reso:utions. which will come up
for final consideration at the massmeeting next Wednesday. The increase in the membership of the
board proposed by these resolutions
is not sufficient to render that body
unwieldy. The resolutions merely
guarantee to the undergraduate
students that power in shaping the
athletic policies of the University
which is their due ; and THE NEWSLETTER can see no reasonable objection which can be urged against
the adoption of the resolutions.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 13, 1912.
THIRD LEAGUE GAME LOST
Lehigh Lacrosse Team Wins First Time
Since Captain Gail Was in Swaddling Clothes- Score,9 to 3.

As a sort of panacea for nearly
a quarter of a century of defeats,
Lehigh managed to slip a score of
9 to 3 over on the 'Varsity last
Compared with the
Saturday.
Homewood "billiard table," the
South Bethlehem field looked as if
some Pennsylvania Dutch farmer
had "turned it under" for a garden.
.Besides this unwonted roughness, a
220-yard straight-away behind one
goal necessitated a complex field
rule which was hard to get used to.
These small annoyances did not
tend to strengthen a team weakened
by the loss of Gillet and Troxell.
To do them justice, however, the
Opposing team was good, showing
the effects of Jack Grimes' training, who for several years coached
Mount Washing-ton. This phenomenal training was chiefly exemplified
in the stick work, the roughness of
which was worthy of the toughest
Canuck in any back alley of Montreal. Our men tried to retaliate,
but showed remarkable lack of
training in this department.
Although we started the scoring,
the first half ended 5 to 1. In the
second period 'Lehigh kept up her
-fast work until three more opals'
were made and then slowed'' up,
sending in many substitutes. Captain Gail then managed 'to get
two goals, but Lehigh immediately'
steadied, and F. L. Speed sent in
the ninth point for Lehigh just as
the game ended.
All of the "subs," Angell, Price,
Sears and Richardson, made good.
These men stemmed the tide of defeat, and for the last, ten minutes
of the game, the 'Varsity had things
its own way. Though two league
games were lost, Captain Gail and
the coaches are to he congratulated
on winning four games out of seven
Saturday.
Captain Kennedy, St. John, Hartegall and Williams were Lehigh's
mainstays, although the work of all
the men was highly commendable.
Captain Gail. Huck and Easter did
best for the 'Varsity. The line-up:
Hopkins—Sutton, g... Schmeisser, p.;
Niles, ca.; Huck, id.; Ellicott, 2d.; Benedict, 3d.: Hollvday, C. Paulus, 3a.;
Everton, 2a..; Gail, ia.; Voshell,
Easter, ill.
Lehigh—Hart, g.; Carson. p.; Rayner,
cn.; F. B. Speed, id.; Hartegan, 2d.;
Kennedy, 3d.; St. John. c.: Buck, 3a.;
Jay, 2a.; Williams, Ia.; Schultz. oh.;
Donaldson, ill.

Buck, Hartegan. Jay, F. B. Speed; Gail
(2), Voshell. Substitutes—Johns Hopkins—Angell for Everton ; Sears for
Ellicott; Richardson for Voshell ; Price
for Benedict. Lehigh—Martin for Schultz,
P. R. Sneed for Donaldson: Perkins for

Johns Honkins; Edwards, Lehigh.. Goal
tunnires—Barger, Johns Hopkins; McConner, Lehigh. Time of halves, 35
minutes.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed with the name of the writer,
which, upon request, will be withheld.)

May II, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

So much might be said apropos
of Mr. B. B's letter in the last issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER that we had
almost decided not to say anything.
But one or two things certainly
should be said. First of all, then,
let us recognize the fact that no
university proposes to give to its
students all the training—mental,
moral, physical and social—which it
is desirable for college graduates
to have. In order to provide for
students this training which the
university authorities think they are
not fitted to give, Y. M. C. A.'s,
athletic associations, glee clubs, literary societies, and fraternities have
been formed by the students themselves. If men know nothing about
the modern religions it is the fault
of the Y. M. C. A., of the churches,
of anybody rather that that of the
university professor. Cardinal
Newman has said that the object
of a university is not to give religious training. If a student graduates from a university weaker
than when he entered, the fault lies
with the athletic association for
taking his $5 locker fee and not giving him a real opportunity to take
physical exercise. A "stag" college should not be expected to teach
social finesse.
The question now naturally arises
whether the interests of the students would best be served if as
Mr. B. B. actually proposes, the
Hopkins faculty took the responsibility of teaching such subjects as
the present-day relation between
the European States. We think
not. Any course about modern
conditions would in the nature of
things be so broad that it would
have to be shallow. Nobody would
take it seriously. Nobody would
like to get into an argument with a
professor who has ideas so fundamentally different from his that
there is no common ground upon
which they could stand: a literary
society, on the other hand, is admirably adapted to disperse knowledge
about modern politics and to sth-nulate interest in good novels and
magazines. A member of such a
society is induced to work hard for
the honors he expects to receive.
All those with whom he has to argue are his equals. Those who get
along well in their lessons can devote a great deal of time to such an
organization; those who need to
spend most of their time on their
lessons, are only required to spend
one hour a week for the meeting.
The English system is no more elastic than this.
